abstract: The decision to detain Mr. Pérez Molina is unprecedented in Guatemalan history and was a stunning conclusion to a day of swift change in the nation.

abstract: Yuengling, the oldest brewery in America, is run by a fifth-generation owner: the 71-year-old patriarch of the family that gives it its name. His four daughters are waiting in the wings.

abstract: The subject of greenhouse gas emissions will be on the table when President Obama hosts President Xi Jinping of China at the White House.

headline: Iran’s Ayatollah Suggests He May Not Be Around in 10 Years
abstract: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei used the 10-year time frame in a speech warning against plots by the United States to subvert Iran when he is gone.

abstract: The 8.3-magnitude temblor struck off the coast, shaking buildings in cities around the country and killing at least eight people.

abstract: The proposed takeover would make the European telecom giant’s American operations the country’s fourth-largest cable company.

abstract: With its admission of fraud in its diesel emissions testing, Volkswagen stands to lose drivers’ trust and the sales comeback it has sought in the United States.

headline: As Indonesia Prospers, Air Pollution Takes Toll
abstract: Years of robust economic growth have put more vehicles in reach and on roadways, and more hazardous pollutants in the air.

headline: Volkswagen Says 11 Million Cars Worldwide Are Affected in Diesel Deception
abstract: The company did not provide information on where the affected cars are, but the overwhelming majority are probably in Europe, where the company dominates the market.

headline: Aleppo Fighting Flares as Syria Insurgents Attack
abstract: In the worst fighting in the divided Syrian city in months, insurgents unleashed rockets and shells, and civilians came under fire from both sides.

headline: Alcoa to Split Into 2 Companies
abstract: The company announced that it would separate its legacy commodity side from its newer businesses, which serve markets such as aerospace and automotive.

headline: Shinzo Abe Faces Growing Wrath of Okinawans Over U.S. Base
abstract: The Japanese prime minister’s determination to push ahead with plans to build a new airfield is emerging as one of his first big political challenges.

headline: Shinzo Abe of Japan Re-elected as Leader of Ruling Party
abstract: Mr. Abe also pledged to push forward with his plan to permit Japan’s military to be dispatched to conflicts abroad.

headline: Despite 5% Increase, Disney Revenue Disappoints Analysts
abstract: Disney’s quarterly results reflected the shifting fortunes of its TV and movie businesses, as cable properties like ESPN took more of a back seat to consumer products.

headline: Shinzo Abe’s Bid to Redefine Japan and Its Military Has Echoes of Family History
abstract: Mr. Abe, who wants the military to take on limited combat roles, sees himself in the mold of his grandfather, who helped redefine cooperation with America.

headline: After Ashley Madison Hack, Police in Toronto Detail a Global Fallout
abstract: The fallout continues from a data breach of Ashley Madison, the adultery website, as international authorities search for the hackers.

headline: U.S. Open Stars Juggle Preparation With Publicity
abstract: The week leading up to the tennis tournament is a marketing extravaganza for companies represented by elite players.

headline: Worldpay Group Plans to Raise $1.4 Billion in I.P.O.
abstract: The British payment processor is to seek a listing on the London Stock Exchange in October.

headline: Fall TV Season Opens Onto a Shifting Ad Landscape
abstract: Traditional television might reach big audiences, but social media outlets like Facebook and Twitter can offer cheaper ways to connect with specific groups.

headline: Norway Again Embraces the Vikings, Minus the Violence
abstract: “Rape and pillage are not part of the curriculum,” said the director of a government-funded course on how to live like a Norse warrior, though image redemption is.

headline: Promoters of Coming ‘Star Wars’ Film Have a Delicate Dance at Comic-Con
abstract: Interest in “The Force Awakens,” due in theaters in December, is already so extreme that Disney knows its safest option is to hold back.

headline: Ads for Podcasts Test the Line Between Story and Sponsor
abstract: Podcast networks like Gimlet Media and Panoply are increasingly relying on a funding model that asks reporters and hosts to help create ads or endorse advertisers’ products.

headline: ‘Nobody Should Be President for Life,’ Obama Tells Africa
abstract: President Obama took on one of the region’s most enduring obstacles to democratic progress: its history of one-man rule by leaders who enrich themselves and hang onto power.
